paragraphs.name: b540
paragraphs.text: So here’s how this works in practice. But a quick word: if you’re just beginning, you’ll really need two days to get the system fully running.

paragraphs.name: 4ea4
paragraphs.text: The truth is most writers struggle with this. Because they believe the myth that writing is one thing. When I realized that coming up with a great idea, writing 500–1,000 words on that idea, and then editing that idea into something I could publish on my blog — all in one sitting — was, in fact, a ridiculous goal, everything changed.

paragraphs.name: a444
paragraphs.text: A system doesn’t have to be complicated or confusing. It just has to work. To quote my friend Tim Grahl, a system is just a way of doing something that gets you a predictable result every time. Like, putting your keys in the same place every day after work (which I only recently started doing).

paragraphs.name: 4ea4
paragraphs.text: The truth is most writers struggle with this. Because they believe the myth that writing is one thing. When I realized that coming up with a great idea, writing 500–1,000 words on that idea, and then editing that idea into something I could publish on my blog — all in one sitting — was, in fact, a ridiculous goal, everything changed.

I began breaking those activities — ideation, creation, and editing — into three separate actions. And you know what? When you have one goal to accomplish, you are far more productive and focused than when you have three.

paragraphs.name: 4ea4
paragraphs.text: The truth is most writers struggle with this. Because they believe the myth that writing is one thing. When I realized that coming up with a great idea, writing 500–1,000 words on that idea, and then editing that idea into something I could publish on my blog — all in one sitting — was, in fact, a ridiculous goal, everything changed.
You can use a notebook for this as well. The tool doesn’t matter, as long as you aren’t just hanging onto all those ideas in your brain. Don’t trust that operating system. It will fail you.
paragraphs.name: 5a1f

paragraphs.text: Totally agree. I came up with the same three steps without integrating them into a system. I’ll have to think about better tools that more easily support the next step in the process. I also collect quotes as I read, making sure to attribute them right then and there. That way I can integrate them into my work later. I may not even have a purpose for…

2263ec11ba7e.title: I’ve just begun to blog about my stock trading.

paragraphs.name: 635a
paragraphs.text: I’ve just begun to blog about my stock trading. I am super unorganized at the moment, bit I am slowly trying to iron out a system that works for me. This system seems to be what will be close to what I end up with. I am familiar with having a system as I am very system and methodology oriented in my trading, so this speaks to me.

virtuals.subtitle: Anyway — thanks for this, it motivates me to try again!

paragraphs.name: d0e0
paragraphs.text: Ugh, this is a really great system, but it is still so hard for me. I used to write 400 words a day, in a manner you described, but after about a month I had a block. It is almost 2 months now and I can’t force myself to write. Of course I write something — I publish blog post from time to time, or few articles here and there. But my goal is to write…
Simple. Actionable. Love it.

paragraphs.name: 8d21
paragraphs.text: For many years I wrote on assignment from editors, so my main challenge was in coming up with a great hook for article. Not too difficult if I could get over my perfectionism and procrastination and get the sucker written by deadline. Or I would propose a topic to cover or a person to profile, again with hook built in. That was the easy part.

paragraphs.name: 86f6
paragraphs.text: You made a good point. I always looked at writing as a process with different steps. Any task will become less complex when you break it down into multiple subtasks. The same applies to writing.

paragraphs.name: 2eaf
paragraphs.text: Thanks for sharing your experiences.

paragraphs.name: 4df3
paragraphs.text: Excellent, Jeff. I do something similar. I put my ideas down on 3 x 5 cards. Then pull one out and write a short chapter. I’m working either on a novella or novel (right now I can’t tell which) and each 500 word exercise is a chapter in the book. I know the themes and the characters so am writing with that in mind. Hopefully, by the time I reach the end of my cards, I’ll be well on my way to completing the work.

paragraphs.text: Jeff, my mother falls victim to this everyday. She comes home from wherever, drops her keys wherever, and a few hours later blasts her voice through the house, “my fucking brain isn’t working!” She has an iPhone. iPhones come packed with more than adequate productivity apps (Notes, Reminders, Calender, and Clock). She doesn’t use them. She depends on…

Evernote : I write down ideas whenever they come to me in Evernote. There is a chance I might not write a blog post on it, but at that time — it is uncertain. I keep on collecting as many ideas as I can.
